page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 4: Line 4:
The following is a chronological summary of the major events that took place during the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]] before [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s resignation as the [[List of Presidents of Egypt|fourth]] [[President of Egypt]].
The following is a chronological summary of the major events that took place during the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]] before [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s resignation as the [[List of Presidents of Egypt|fourth]] [[President of Egypt]].
â
From 2000 to 2010, Hosni Mubarak was in power under [[Emergency Law]] with his son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] appearing the likely successor to the presidency. In December 2010 protests in [[Tunisia]] sparked by the death of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] turned into [[Tunisian revolution|a revolution]]. The death of [[Khaled Saeed]] in June of 2010 became a similar rallying point for activists in Egypt. Increasing use of social media among activists centered around plans for a nationwide protest on 25 January 2011.
+
From 1981 to 2011, Hosni Mubarak was in power under [[Emergency Law]] with his son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] appearing the likely successor to the presidency. In December 2010 protests in [[Tunisia]] sparked by the death of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] turned into [[Tunisian revolution|a revolution]]. The death of [[Khaled Saeed]] in June of 2010 became a similar rallying point for activists in Egypt. Increasing use of social media among activists centered around plans for a nationwide protest on 25 January 2011.
Millions turned out to major cities in Egypt on the 25th, especially in Cairo's [[Tahrir square]]. At first tensions were high between the police and protesters with violence breaking out in [[Suez]] and [[Alexandria]]. The government took a hard line, using riot-control tactics, and shutting down communications. But by the 28th the protests were continuing and the police had retreated. The security role was taken over by the military, and from then on the situation remained almost entirely peaceful. As pressure rose on Mubarak, the scale of the protests continued to grow, especially on specially organized Friday rallies.
Millions turned out to major cities in Egypt on the 25th, especially in Cairo's [[Tahrir square]]. At first tensions were high between the police and protesters with violence breaking out in [[Suez]] and [[Alexandria]]. The government took a hard line, using riot-control tactics, and shutting down communications. But by the 28th the protests were continuing and the police had retreated. The security role was taken over by the military, and from then on the situation remained almost entirely peaceful. As pressure rose on Mubarak, the scale of the protests continued to grow, especially on specially organized Friday rallies.
